questions.text: A 25-year-old woman visits her therapist to discuss her interpersonal relationships. During the session, the therapist reviews the Five-Factor Model of personality traits to help the patient better understand herself and others. Which of the following is NOT considered one of the five main personality traits in the Five-Factor Model?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Introversion

 

Option C:

 

The Five-Factor Model, also known as the Big Five personality traits, includes the following dimensions: Openness to Experience, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism. Introversion is not one of the five main traits; instead, it is considered the opposite pole of Extraversion. While Extraversion is characterized by sociability, assertiveness, and talkativeness, Introversion is marked by a preference for solitude, reserved behavior, and less engagement in social situations. In the context of the Five-Factor Model, traits related to introversion would be captured under the dimension of Extraversion (or low Extraversion).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Openness to Experience: This trait features characteristics such as imagination, curiosity, and a wide range of interests.

 

Option B. Conscientiousness: This dimension includes traits such as organization, dependability, and discipline.

 

Option D. Agreeableness: This trait is associated with being cooperative, compassionate, and friendly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Five-Factor Model (also known as the Big Five) is a widely accepted model of personality traits that includes the following dimensions:

 

 

Ref: Psychology Themes and Variations, 10th edition, Page 381.

choices.text: The prevalence of personality disorders in the general population is approximately 10%.
Personality disorders typically have an onset in adolescence or early adulthood.
Individuals with personality disorders usually perceive their thoughts and behaviors as ego-syntonic.
SSRIs are considered the first-line treatment for personality disorders.

questions.text: A clinical psychologist is discussing personality disorders with a group of medical students. Which of the following statements regarding personality disorders is NOT true?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) SSRIs are considered the first-line treatment for personality disorders.

 

Option D:

 

Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRIs) are not considered the first-line treatment for personality disorders. Treatment for personality disorders typically involves psychotherapy as the mainstay, such as cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT), dialectical behavior therapy (DBT), or other forms of therapy tailored to the specific type of personality disorder and the individual's needs. Medications may be used to treat specific symptoms or comorbid conditions associated with personality disorders, but there is no single medication or class of medications that is universally effective for all personality disorders.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. The prevalence of personality disorders in the general population is approximately 10%: This statement is generally considered true based on epidemiological studies, although prevalence rates can vary depending on the specific type of personality disorder and the assessment methods used.

 

Option B. Personality disorders typically have an onset in adolescence or early adulthood: This statement is true. Personality disorders usually begin in adolescence or early adulthood, as personality traits become more stable during these periods.

 

Option C. Individuals with personality disorders usually perceive their thoughts and behaviours as ego-syntonic: This statement is true. One of the characteristics of personality disorders is that individuals often view their maladaptive patterns of thinking and behavior as normal or justified (ego-syntonic), which can make them resistant to recognizing their condition or seeking treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Personality disorders are characterized by persistent and maladaptive patterns of behavior, cognition, and inner experience. These disorders typically begin in adolescence or early adulthood and are often ego-syntonic, meaning individuals may not see their behavior as problematic. Psychotherapy, not SSRIs, is the cornerstone of treatment for personality disorders, although medications may be used to address specific symptoms or comorbid conditions.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 571.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the clinic with a history of interpersonal difficulties and mistrust of others. He reports that he is constantly suspicious of his co-workers and believes they are plotting against him. He avoids confiding in others, fearing that the information he shares will be used against him. He is easily offended and has a tendency to hold grudges. He denies any history of delusions or hallucinations. Which of the following personality disorders best describes his condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Paranoid personality disorder

 

Option B:

 

The patient's history of interpersonal difficulties, mistrust of others, and suspiciousness without any reported delusions or hallucinations aligns with the diagnostic criteria for paranoid personality disorder. Paranoid Personality Disorder is a chronic and pervasive pattern of distrust and suspicion of others, such that their motives are interpreted as malevolent. These individuals often hold grudges, are hypersensitive to setbacks, and can perceive hidden, demeaning, or threatening meanings in benign comments or events.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by odd and eccentric behavior, odd beliefs and magical thinking, but the patient's presentation does not include these features.

 

Option C. Antisocial personality disorder is characterized by a disregard for the rights of others, and deceitfulness, which is not consistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Option D. Borderline personality disorder is characterized by unstable relationships, impulsivity, and emotional instability, which is also not consistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paranoid Personality Disorder is characterized by excessive suspiciousness and pervasive distrust and suspicion of others, interpreting their motives as malevolent, even in the absence of objective evidence. They give excessive importance to themselves and believe in conspiracy theories. These patients may be excessively sensitive and may be quick to react angrily. Psychotherapy is the treatment of choice.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 562.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents to the clinic with complaints of feeling socially disconnected. His coworker referred him for evaluation, as he is known to be a "loner" at work. He rarely interacts with others and appears uninterested in forming relationships. The patient has no history of depression or anxiety and denies any substance abuse. He states that he prefers solitary activities and has little desire for close friendships or romantic relationships. He has a steady job as a software programmer and does not experience any difficulties with his performance at work. Which of the following personality disorders is most likely to describe the patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Schizoid personality disorder

 

Option A:

 

Schizoid personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of detachment from social relationships and a restricted range of emotional expression. Individuals with this disorder prefer solitary activities, have little interest in forming close relationships, and generally appear emotionally cold or indifferent to others.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Schizotypal personality disorder is characterized by eccentric behavior, odd beliefs and magical thinking. This patient does not display any such symptoms.

 

Option C. Borderline personality disorder typically presents with unstable interpersonal relationships, impulsivity, self-image disturbances, and emotional dysregulation. The patient does not exhibit these features.

 

Option D. Avoidant personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of social inhibition, feelings of inadequacy, and fear of rejection due to which social activities are avoided. The patient's lack of interest in social relationships is not due to fear of rejection or criticism, and hence avoidant personality disorder is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with Schizoid Personality Disorder, a Cluster A personality disorder, are detached from social relationships and prefer solitary activities. They are emotionally cold and indifferent to praise or criticism. They appear self-absorbed and lost in daydreams and may be preoccupied with fantasies. 

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 562-563.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to a psychiatrist for evaluation. She reports that she has difficulty maintaining relationships, as her friends and romantic partners often find her behavior "overwhelming" or "dramatic." She frequently seeks attention from others and becomes upset if she is not the center of attention. Her emotional expressions seem exaggerated and overly theatrical. When interacting with others, she tends to be flirtatious, even in inappropriate situations. Based on the clinical presentation, which of the following personality disorders is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Histrionic Personality Disorder

 

Option C:

 

The clinical presentation described is most consistent with Histrionic Personality Disorder (HPD). Individuals with HPD exhibit a pattern of excessive emotionality and attention-seeking behavior. They often feel uncomfortable when they are not the center of attention and may use physical appearance, flirtatious behavior, and exaggerated emotional expressions to gain attention. Their emotions can seem shallow and rapidly shifting, and they may engage in dramatic, theatrical, and exaggerated displays of emotion.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Borderline Personality Disorder is characterized by unstable interpersonal relationships, unstable self-image, impulsivity, and emotional dysregulation, which differ from the patient's presentation.

 

Option B. Narcissistic Personality Disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of grandiosity, need for admiration, and lack of empathy, which are not the primary issues described in this case.

 

Option D. Dependent Personality Disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of submissive and clinging behavior, which is not consistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Educational objective:

 

The individuals with histrionic PD exhibit:

 

  • Dramatic & exaggerated emotions
  • Need to be the centre of attention
  • Behave in a sexually seductive way & use physical appearance for attention
  • Management- Psychotherapy, antidepressants

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 564-565.

questions.text: 32-year-old male presents to his primary care physician for a regular checkup. During the visit, the patient talks at length about his high-level job, which he believes he deserves because of his superior intelligence and skills. He frequently interrupts the physician, and boasts how he can make a better diagnosis than many doctors due to his deep knowledge in most of the fields, and also seems uninterested in the concerns of other patients in the waiting room. He appears to have difficulty empathizing with others and becomes visibly upset when someone disagrees with his opinions. Based on this information, which of the following personality disorders best describes this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Narcissistic Personality Disorder

 

Option B:

 

Narcissistic Personality Disorder is characterized by an inflated sense of self-importance, a need for admiration, and a lack of empathy, which are consistent with the patient's behavior and attitudes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Borderline Personality Disorder is characterized by emotional instability, impulsivity, and unstable relationships, which are not the primary features presented by the patient.

 

Option C. Antisocial Personality Disorder is characterized by a disregard for the rights of others, deceitfulness, and a lack of remorse, which are not the primary features presented by the patient.

 

Option D. Histrionic Personality Disorder is characterized by excessive emotionality, attention-seeking behavior, and a strong need for approval, which are not the primary features presented by the patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Individuals with narcissistic personality disorders have the following characteristics:

 

  • Give excessive self-importance (grandiose)
  • Have beliefs about being special and talented
  • Have fantasies of unlimited success and power
  • Have poor tolerance for criticism
  • Underlying fragile self-esteem is there.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page 565.

questions.text: A 23-year-old medical student presents to the surgery emergency department after cutting her wrist with a blade. After receiving first aid, the resident notices multiple healed cut marks on her wrist. Upon psychiatry referral, the patient informs the resident that she cut herself because she was feeling very angry at her boyfriend who spent the entire evening watching an IPL match rather than calling her. She also mentions that she has never been in a relationship with a guy for more than 2 months and believes that all men are horrible, while women are the best. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Borderline Personality Disorder

 

Option B:

 

A pattern of unstable interpersonal relationships, self-harming behaviour, black-and-white thinking about men and women are all consistent with a diagnosis of Borderline Personality Disorder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Histrionic Personality Disorder is characterized by exaggerated emotions and attention-seeking behavior. 

 

Option C. Narcissistic Personality Disorder is characterized by excessive self importance (grandiose), fantasies of unlimited success and power and poor tolerance to criticism

 

Option D. Dependent Personality Disorder is characterized by an excessive need to be taken care of, submissive behavior, and a fear of separation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with Borderline Personality Disorder are almost always in a state of crisis. They have significant mood swings. They may start feeling angry, anxious or frustrated without any reason. Their interpersonal relationships are intense and tumultuous. They swing from being excessively dependent to being hostile to persons close to them. Hence, they have a history of unstable relationships. Another characteristic feature is the repetitive self-destructive acts such as the slashing of wrists, or overdosage of medications. The patients indulge in these behaviors to elicit help from others, to express their anger or just to numb themselves to the overwhelming painful feelings they have. These patients are also impulsive in areas such as spending, sex, and substance use. These patients have identity disturbances and unstable self-images (they have sudden changes in life goals, values, career plans, sexual identity, etc).

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 564.

questions.text: A middle-aged actor has been referred for a psychological evaluation. His history reveals numerous incidents of aggressive behavior, including physical altercations and violence toward romantic partners, leading to breakups. He has a history of substance use and was once involved in a drunk driving accident, hitting several individuals who were sleeping on the streets. Additionally, the actor has broken the law by hunting deer in a wildlife sanctuary. He has never expressed remorse for his actions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Antisocial Personality Disorder

 

Option A:

 

Antisocial Personality Disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of disregard for the rights of others, deceitfulness, and lack of remorse. The actor's history of aggressive behavior, substance use, law-breaking, and absence of remorse is consistent with this diagnosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Borderline Personality Disorder is characterized by emotional instability, impulsivity, and unstable relationships. While the actor has had unstable relationships, the other main features of borderline personality disorder are not evident.

 

Option C. Narcissistic Personality Disorder is characterized by an inflated sense of self-importance, a need for admiration, and a lack of empathy. These are not the primary features presented by the actor.

 

Option D. Histrionic Personality Disorder is characterized by excessive emotionality, attention-seeking behavior, and a strong need for approval. These are not the primary features presented by the actor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) do not have regard for the rights of others and frequently violate them. They frequently get involved in unlawful behaviors such as theft, lying, truancy, and conning. They have a lack of remorse or guilt for their actions. Substance use disorder is the most common comorbid psychiatric condition observed in these patients. Treatment usually is psychotherapy. Medications like carbamazepine and β-blockers are occasionally used.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 569.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the clinic for a routine checkup. She mentions that she is a second year pathology resident, and she chose the field because her father, a doctor, encouraged her to do so, although she originally was inclined towards surgery. She reads the books recommended by her father and allows her mother to choose her clothes. She had feelings for a classmate but married the man her father selected for her because she was unsure of her own decision. Now, she follows her parents' advice regarding family planning. Based on the patient's history, which of the following personality disorders is most likely?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Dependent Personality Disorder

 

Option C:

 

The patient's history suggests a pattern of pervasive and excessive need to be taken care of, leading to submissive and clinging behavior and a fear of separation. This is consistent with a diagnosis of Dependent Personality Disorder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Borderline Personality Disorder is characterized by a pattern of unstable relationships, marked impulsivity and deliberate self-harming behaviours.

 

Option B. Narcissistic Personality Disorder involves a pervasive pattern of grandiosity, a need for admiration, and a lack of empathy for others.

 

Option D. Histrionic Personality Disorder is characterized by excessive emotionality and attention-seeking behavior.

 

Educational objective:

 

The individuals with dependent PD- These individuals have the following characteristics:

 

  • Let others take decisions for their lives
  • Need reassurance for mundane decisions too
  • Get uncomfortable when alone
  • Treatment- Psychotherapy, beta-blockers, SSRIs

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 574.

questions.text: A 55-year-old medical college principal is known for his strict adherence to rules and regulations. He recently denied several students the opportunity to appear for final exams because their attendance fell short by just 1% due to COVID-19, insisting that "rules are rules." During the annual college festival, he is known to stop students from dancing exactly at 9 pm by personally standing on the dance floor and stopping everyone around him, as per the college rules. He is resistant to incorporating technological tools into teaching, claiming that reading from PowerPoint presentations in class has produced great doctors for decades. The principal also becomes irritable when students laugh during lectures, frequently threatening to mark them absent. Based on this description, which of the following personality disorders best fits the principal?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder

 

Option C: 

 

The principal's behavior aligns with the characteristics of Obsessive-Compulsive Personality Disorder (OCPD). Individuals with OCPD are often preoccupied with rules, orderliness, and control. They may be inflexible and resistant to change, as seen in the principal's unwillingness to adapt to new teaching methods. This rigidity, excessive conscientiousness, and adherence to rules distinguish OCPD from the other personality disorders listed in the options.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Antisocial Personality Disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of disregard for the rights of others, deceitfulness, and lack of remorse

 

Option B. Borderline Personality Disorder is characterized by a pattern of unstable relationships, marked impulsivity and deliberate self-harming behaviours.

 

Option D. Histrionic Personality Disorder is characterized by excessive emotionality and attention-seeking behavior.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with Anankastic personality disorder are preoccupied with rules and regulations. They give excessive importance to details and show perfectionism that interferes with task completion (since they want everything to be perfect, it often results in significant delays). They are inflexible and insist that others agree to their demands. They are excessively devoted to work and may not have any time for leisure activities. They are formal and serious and often lack a sense of humor. The DSM-5 uses the diagnosis of "obsessive-compulsive personality disorder" for these patients. Management usually involves psychotherapy.

 

Ref:  Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 566.

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman presents to the emergency room after an episode of self-harm. She mentions feeling "empty inside" and expresses fear that people will abandon her. Her relationships are described as intense but unstable, and she has a history of impulsive behavior including substance use and promiscuity. She often experiences rapid mood swings within a day, going from intense anger to feelings of detachment from reality. Based on her presentation, which of the following personality disorders is she most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Borderline Personality Disorder.

 

Option D:

 

The clinical presentation of the 23-year-old woman is characteristic of Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD). BPD is characterized by a pattern of intense and unstable relationships, an ongoing pattern of varying moods, self-image, and behavior. These symptoms often result in impulsive actions and problems in relationships. Key features include fear of abandonment, feelings of emptiness, frequent mood changes, anger, suicidal behavior or self-harm, and sometimes a feeling of detachment from reality (dissociation).

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Histrionic Personality Disorder: This disorder is characterized by a pattern of seeking attention and being excessively emotional. Individuals with this disorder are uncomfortable when they are not the center of attention, may use their appearance to draw attention or be easily influenced by others.

 

Option B. Narcissistic Personality Disorder: People with this disorder have a grandiose sense of their own importance and a need for excessive admiration. They believe they are unique and superior and may be envious of others or believe others are envious of them.

 

Option C. Antisocial Personality Disorder: Characterized by a pattern of disregard for, and violation of, the rights of others. People with this disorder often repeatedly perform acts that are grounds for arrest, deceive for personal gain, and may show aggressive behavior.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with Borderline Personality Disorder are almost always in a state of crisis. They have significant mood swings. They may start feeling angry, anxious or frustrated without any reason. Their interpersonal relationships are intense and tumultuous. They swing from being excessively dependent to being hostile to persons close to them. Hence, they have a history of unstable relationships. Another characteristic feature is the repetitive self-destructive acts such as the slashing of wrists, or overdosage of medications. The patients indulge in these behaviors to elicit help from others, to express their anger or just to numb themselves to the overwhelming painful feelings they have. These patients are also impulsive in areas such as spending, sex, and substance use. These patients have identity disturbances and unstable self-images (they have sudden changes in life goals, values, career plans sexual identity, etc).

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 564.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the psychiatric clinic complaining of intense mood swings, and impulsive behavior. She describes periods where she feels detached from herself and her surroundings. She has a history of self-harm and frequently engages in risky behaviors. However, she mentions having a few close and stable relationships that she has maintained for years. Which of the following characteristics is not typically associated with her most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Strong interpersonal relationships

 

Option C:

 

Strong interpersonal relationships is not a characteristic of BPD. In fact, individuals with BPD usually have turbulent and unstable relationships. They fear abandonment and may exhibit splitting behavior (seeing others as entirely good or entirely bad). This makes maintaining stable and healthy relationships challenging.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Dissociative events: Patients with BPD can experience feelings of detachment from themselves or their surroundings.

  

Option B. Identity crisis: Individuals with BPD often struggle with self-image, self-identity, and their role in the world.

  

Option D. Risk-taking behavior: Impulsivity and risky behaviors (like substance abuse, reckless driving, or unsafe sexual encounters) are common in BPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with borderline personality disorder typically have unstable interpersonal relationships, along with other features such as dissociative events, identity issues, and risk-taking behaviors.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 564.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of borderline personality disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Grandiose self-importance

 

Option B:

 

Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is characterized by a pervasive pattern of instability in relationships, self-image, and affects, as well as marked impulsivity. Features such as unstable interpersonal relationships, chronic feelings of emptiness, and repetitive self-harm behaviors are commonly associated with BPD. Grandiose self-importance is typically not a feature of BPD; it is more characteristic of narcissistic personality disorder.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Unstable interpersonal relationships are a hallmark of BPD, often swinging from intense closeness and love (idealization) to intense dislike or anger (devaluation).

 

Option C. A chronic feeling of emptiness is commonly reported by individuals with BPD and is a criterion for the diagnosis.

 

Option D. Repetitive self-harm is a behavior often associated with BPD as a maladaptive coping mechanism to deal with emotional pain or as a result of impulsivity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Borderline PD (emotionally unstable PD) is characterized by emotional instability, impulsivity, intense but unstable relationships, indulge in self-injurious behaviour (e.g. cutting the wrist, overdosage of medications) and identity disturbances, unstable self-image.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 564.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with a known diagnosis of borderline personality disorder presents to the psychiatric clinic for a routine follow-up. During the session, she describes a recent argument with her boyfriend, saying, "One minute he's my soulmate, and the next minute, I feel like he's the worst person ever." She often experiences rapid shifts in her view of people, categorizing them as "all good" or "all bad" with no middle ground. This defense mechanism is best described as:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Splitting.

 

Option C:

 

Splitting is a defense mechanism commonly associated with borderline personality disorder. It involves viewing people or events in extremes—either all good or all bad, with no gray area in between. This black-and-white thinking prevents the individual from having a balanced and coherent sense of people or situations. In the scenario described, the patient's rapid shifts from viewing her boyfriend as her soulmate to seeing him as the worst person exemplifies splitting.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Reaction formation: This defense mechanism involves behaving in a way that is exactly opposite to one's unacceptable thoughts or feelings. For example, a person who harbours hostile feelings might excessively act out with kindness.

 

Option B. Regression: Refers to reverting back to a childlike emotional state in which unconscious fears, anxieties, and general "childish" defensive reactions dominate behavior. 

 

Option D. Denial: Refers to refusing to accept real events because they are unpleasant. It might involve ignoring or refusing to believe the harsh truth.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Individuals with borderline personality disorder frequently use the defense mechanism of splitting, wherein they view others as either entirely good or entirely bad.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 564.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman is diagnosed with borderline personality disorder after multiple presentations to the psychiatric clinic, each time with intense interpersonal issues, impulsivity, and self-harm tendencies. As part of her comprehensive treatment plan, which therapeutic approach has been shown to be the most effective in managing individuals with this disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT).

 

Option B.

 

Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is a challenging condition to treat. However, Dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) has been specifically developed for, and has shown to be the most effective for, BPD patients, particularly those with a history of self-harm or suicidal behaviors. DBT is a form of cognitive-behavioral therapy that focuses on teaching coping skills to combat destructive urges, improve relationships, and increase emotional awareness.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT): While CBT can be useful for certain symptoms and can be a part of the treatment regime, DBT is the primary therapeutic approach specifically designed for BPD.

 

Option C. Group therapy: Group therapy can be beneficial in treating some aspects of BPD, but it isn't the primary therapeutic modality used for this condition.

 

Option D. Psychodynamic psychotherapy: While this approach can offer insights into unconscious thought patterns and behaviors, it's not the first-line therapy for BPD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dialectical behavior therapy is a therapy that has been designed for the treatment of borderline personality disorder. Medications used in BPD include antipsychotics, antidepressants, and mood stabilizers like carbamazepine.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadocks Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 573.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with a known history of Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD) is brought to the clinic by his brother. Over the years, he has shown consistent disregard for the rights of others, impulsiveness, and deceitfulness, and has had multiple arrests. Which of the following psychiatric conditions is most commonly comorbid with Antisocial Personality Disorder?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Substance use disorder.

 

Option D:

 

Individuals with Antisocial Personality Disorder (ASPD) often display a pattern of disregard for the rights of others, impulsiveness, irritability, deceitfulness, and consistent irresponsibility. Among those with ASPD, substance use disorder is frequently observed as a comorbid condition. Many times, their reckless behaviors and disregard for their own safety can lead to increased substance use and addiction.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Obsessive-compulsive disorder: While individuals with ASPD might display repetitive behaviors, these are not typically due to the obsessions and compulsions that characterize OCD.

 

Option B. Major depressive disorder: While depression can be comorbid with many other psychiatric conditions, it is not the most common comorbidity with ASPD.

 

Option C. Schizophrenia: There's no strong correlation between ASPD and schizophrenia. Both conditions can co-exist, but one doesn't predispose to the other.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients with antisocial personality disorder (ASPD) do not have regard for the rights of others and frequently violate them. They frequently get involved in unlawful behaviors such as theft, lying, truancy, and conning. They have a lack of remorse or guilt for their actions. Substance use disorder is the most common comorbid psychiatric condition observed in these patients. Treatment usually is psychotherapy. Medications like carbamazepine and β-blockers are occasionally used.

 

Ref: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 569.

choices.text: Diagnosed based on severity and predominant personality traits
Based on the presence of psychotic symptoms
Diagnosed only in individuals above 30 years of age

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman presents to the psychiatric clinic with a history of unstable relationships, impulsive behavior, and intense episodes of anger. She reports a chronic feeling of emptiness and struggles with self-identity. Her psychiatrist considers a personality disorder diagnosis as per ICD-11 criteria. Which of the following best describes the classification of personality disorders in ICD-11?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diagnosed based on severity and predominant personality traits

 

Option B.

 

The International Classification of Diseases, 11th Revision (ICD-11) has adopted a new approach to classifying personality disorders. Unlike the previous version, ICD-11 does not categorize personality disorders into specific types (such as borderline, antisocial, etc.). Instead, it focuses on the severity of the dysfunction (mild, moderate, or severe) and predominant personality traits or patterns that can be described in terms of five broad domains: negative affectivity, detachment, dissociality, disinhibition, and anankastia. The new classification is intended to reduce overlap between diagnoses and to provide a more flexible framework that can capture the full range of personality pathology.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Categorized into 10 specific types: This describes the classification system used by the DSM-5, not ICD-11.

 

Option C. Based on the presence of psychotic symptoms: Psychotic symptoms are not used to classify personality disorders in ICD-11. Personality disorders are characterized by enduring patterns of behavior and inner experience that deviate markedly from the expectations of the individual's culture, are pervasive and inflexible, and lead to distress or impairment.

 

Option D. Diagnosed only in individuals above 30 years of age: Personality disorders can be diagnosed in adults of any age, not just those above 30, as long as the maladaptive patterns are stable over time and lead to distress or impairment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In ICD-11, the older classification of personality disorders (e.g. schizoid, paranoid, narcissistic, etc) has been removed. According to ICD-11, personality disorders have been divided according to the severity of symptoms into:

 

  • Mild personality disorder

  • Moderate personality disorder

  • Severe personality disorder

 

According to ICD-11, depending on the specific symptoms present, a specifier of a prominent personality trait' can be added after the diagnosis, e.g. a person who does not follow rules doesn't care for the feelings of others, does not have any guilt feeling will get a diagnosis of moderate personality disorder (dissociality in personality disorder). This patient according to ICD-10 would have received a diagnosis of Dissocial Personality disorder.

 

Ref: International Classification of Diseases, 11th edition, Page No 174-177.
